election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1824 Electoral College

overview.note: Only Adams County and Perry County reported votes for individual electors. All other counties only reported the votes for the tickets as a whole. The votes for those listed first on each ticket are those votes for the tickets as a whole.

Many newspapers reported differing amounts, at both the county and state level. The listed returns are the official returns. The county totals are those reported by various newspapers which add up to the official totals. Some differ from the official returns, in that they contain townships whose totals were rejected. They are noted.

"One election has just been terminated, but let not the people forget that another is approaching, at which they will have an opportunity of rewarding one of the last heroes of the revolutionary war. On the 29th day of this month, rememeber that you have to vote for electors of President and Vice President. You will have a ticket of twenty-eight candidates, yet recollect that the candidates, as published in our paper, stand pledged to the Central Committee, to vote for General Andrew Jackson and John C. Calhoun. Can you, or will you prove ungrateful to such a man as Jackson, who, fearless of consequences to himself, at all hazards protected New Orleans from the brutality of an invading force - who drove that force from your shores, retrieved the character of your country, and then cheerfully submitted to the civil authority of the land, and returned to the walks of private life. To such a man, can a republic be ungrateful?" The Pennsylvanian (Harrisburg, PA). October 16, 1824.

"The democratic citizens, who are solicitous to preserve the consolidated force and harmony of the party to which they belong, will zealously cooperate throughout the state of Pennsylvania in increasing the majority for the electoral ticket pledged for JACKSON and CALHOUN. In the formation of no other ticket in this state have the principles or practices of the republican party been regarded or adhered to. The CRAWFORD ticket was got up by a few men in Philadelphia, who, though they notoriously participated in the election of representative members to the Harrisburg convention, and solemnly profesed a resolution to abide by its decision, became disatisfied, flew the course, and are no formally arrayed in opposition to the only regular nomination known to us. The CLAY ticket, very unlike the distinguished and meritorious statesman whom it pretends to uphold, emanated from an heterogeneous mixture of republicans and federalists, and is really scarcely thought of beyond the boundaries of this district. The HALF ADAMS ticket, we speak it with regret and mortification, is an exclusively federal production." Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA). October 19, 1824.

"No electoral ticket has been formed in favor of Mr. CLAY, and in our opinion, it is too late to form one with any hope of showing his strength at the poll. At an earlier day an electoral ticket might have been formed for him which would have been respectfully supported." Village Record, or Chester and Delaware Federalist (West Chester, PA). October 20, 1824.

"We presume that the Kentucky Argus, in announcing to its readers 'that the friends of General JACKSON in Pennsylvania were abandoning him and going over to Mr. CLAY,' and that in congress Pennsylvania will vote for Mr. CLAY in opposition to General JACKSON, deliberately studied and hoped to produce an effect in that quarter in favor of the one against the other. It surely could not have credited its own statement. For us to repeat our great respect for the abilities and patriotism of Mr. CLAY, would be superfluou: That very respect, if nothing else, would induce a regret that any of his friends should deem themselves to be rendering him any service by disparaging the claims or standing of the hero of Orleans. Ten days more will demonstrate the utter fallacy of the idea, that the friends of General JACKSON are abandoning him in Pennsylvania; and the impolicy will then be seen of trying the strength of any other candidate in this state. In relation to our members of congress, a large majority of them are in favor of General JACKSON; and if, unfortunately, the election should go into the house of representatives, they will vote for him." Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA). October 22, 1824.

"We are not much given to guessing at the probable results of elections; but we will hazard, from the knowledge we possess of the present state of politics, that Gen. Jackson cannot, in any way, be elected President of the U.S. The contests, as we before stated, is between Wm. H. Crawford, the democratic, and J. Q. Adams, the federal candidate; and though we may not be be believed, we do say, that every person who votes for Jackson, is indirectly aiding the cause of Adams. Many who appear to be zealously engaged in supporting the 'Hero of Orleans,' are, in reality, 'laughing in their sleeves' at the prospect they have of duping, and thereby dividing, the democratic party. We hope the people will open their eyes before it is too late." Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA). October 23, 1824.

Isaac Smith was elected an elector but did not vote. "On calling over the list of electors, it appeared that Isaac Smith was absent, being detained a few miles from Harrisburg by sickness: his vacancy was supplied by choosing James Clarke, of Westmoreland in his place. Some discussion arose on this subject, Mr. Beatty suggesting that the vacancy ought to be filled by the selection of an original friend of General Jackson, and moving that a written pledge should be required from Mr. Clark (sic) that he would vote for the General. This was opposed by Mr. M'Caraher of Philadelphia county, and Mr. Engle of Deleware county, who said that it was enough for them to know that Mr. Clarke was a friend to General Jackson, and would vote for him. Mr Beatty's motion was negatived, only five rising in its favour. Mr Murray and Mr. Engle were appointed tellers: The balloting then took place, and the result was that Andrew Jackson received all the votes of Pennsylvania for President, and John C. Calhoun, all the votes for Vice President." American Volunteer (Carlisle, PA). December 9, 1824.
Walter Franklin, Jr., Alexander L. Hays and John Negley were all listed on the William H. Crawford ticket but declined to serve on the ticket.

sub_unit.name: Adams
sub_unit.note: "The Crawford Ticket had not a single vote in this county." The Republican Compiler (Gettysburg, PA). November 3, 1824.
Adams Centinel (Gettysburg, PA) lists Daniel Sheffer with 388 votes, Clement C. Biddle with 348 votes and James MacSherry with 349 votes.

sub_unit.name: Allegheny
sub_unit.note: "The election was thinly attended. The total amount of votes given was 1833. At the previous election, on the 12th ult. there were 2897 votes polled." Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA). November 6, 1824.

Pittsburg Recorder (Pittsburgh, PA) and the Pittsburgh Gazette, and Manufacturing and Mercantile Advertiser (Pittsburgh, PA) both list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 1385 votes and have township totals that add up to 1385 votes.
Pittsburg Recorder (Pittsburgh, PA) lists the John Quincy Adams ticket with 19 votes in spite of having township totals that add up to the correct total of 18 votes.
Pittsburg Recorder (Pittsburgh, PA) lists the Henry Clay ticket with 26 votes.

The Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 1386 votes, the John Quincy Adams ticket with 19 votes, the Henry Clay ticket with 26 votes and the William H. Crawford ticket with 402 votes.

sub_unit.name: Mifflin
sub_unit.note: The Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA) lists the William H. Crawford ticket with 59 votes.

sub_unit.name: Robinson
sub_unit.note: The Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 50 votes.

sub_unit.name: Ross
sub_unit.note: Pittsburg Recorder (Pittsburgh, PA) lists the Henry Clay ticket with 1 vote.
The Pittsburgh Gazette, and Manufacturing and Mercantile Advertiser (Pittsburgh, PA) lists the Henry Clay ticket with no votes.
The Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA) and Pittsburgh Gazette, and Manufacturing and Mercantile Advertiser (Pittsburgh, PA) list the William H. Crawford ticket with 12 votes.

sub_unit.name: Saint Clair
sub_unit.note: The Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA) and Pittsburgh Gazette, and Manufacturing and Mercantile Advertiser (Pittsburgh, PA) list Saint Clair township as "M'Culley's.".

sub_unit.name: Wilkins
sub_unit.note: The Butler Sentinel (Butler, PA) lists the John Quincy Adams ticket with 1 vote.

sub_unit.name: Berks
sub_unit.note: The Berks and Schuylkill Journal (Reading, PA) and Der Readinger Adler (Reading, PA), which list the township totals, list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 1676 votes, the John Quincy Adams ticket with 67 votes and the Henry Clay ticket with 41 votes.

sub_unit.name: Heidleberg (Womelsdorf)
sub_unit.note: The returns were listed as Heidleberg (Womelsdorf). Womelsdorf is a borough located in Heidleberg township.

sub_unit.name: Robeson (Forest)
sub_unit.note: No returns made.

sub_unit.name: Windsor
sub_unit.note: Der Readinger Adler (Reading, PA) lists the Windsor returns as Hamburg. Hamburg is a borough located in Windsor township.

sub_unit.name: Bradford
sub_unit.note: "The electoral ticket for Mr. CYAY (sic) did not arrive here until after election." Bradford Settler (Towanda, PA). November 4, 1824.

sub_unit.name: Asylum
sub_unit.note: "Some scattering." Bradford Settler (Towanda, PA). November 4, 1824.

sub_unit.name: Athens
sub_unit.note: "Some scattering." Bradford Settler (Towanda, PA). November 4, 1824.

sub_unit.name: Sheshequin
sub_unit.note: The Bradford Settler (Towanda, PA) lists 2 scattering.

sub_unit.name: Cambria
sub_unit.note: The History of Cambria County lists the votes for the William H. Crawford ticket as being for the Henry Clay ticket.

sub_unit.name: Chester
sub_unit.note: The friends of Mr. CRAWFORD, have formed the Ticket which follows. In this County, although some of our most estimable Democratic citizens will support it, the number of votes it will received cannot, we think, be very considerable." Village Record, or Chester and Delaware Federalist (West Chester, PA). October 20, 1824.

sub_unit.name: Dauphin
sub_unit.note: The Harrisburg Chronicle (Harrisburg, PA) and Pennsylvania Intelligencer (Harrisburg, PA), which list the township totals, list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 772 votes and the John Quincy Adams ticket with 124 votes.

sub_unit.name: Harrisburg
sub_unit.note: The Cheraw Intelligencer and Southern Register (Cheraw, SC) lists the John Quincy Adams ticket with 34 votes.

sub_unit.name: Huntingdon
sub_unit.note: The Huntingdon Gazette (Huntingdon, PA), which lists the township totals, lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 468 votes.

sub_unit.name: Indiana
sub_unit.note: The votes from Jefferson County which was still unorganized were included with Indiana County.

sub_unit.name: Lancaster
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, which lists the township totals, lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 1667 votes and the John Quincy Adams ticket with 204 votes.

sub_unit.name: Lehigh
sub_unit.note: "At the presidential election, there will not be twenty votes, if that, in this county, against JACKSON and CALHOUN." Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA). October 19, 1824.

sub_unit.name: Luzerne
sub_unit.note: The Susquehanna Democrat lists the Andrew Jackson electors with 632 votes and the Crawford electors with 126 votes.

sub_unit.name: Lycoming
sub_unit.note: The votes from McKean and Potter Counties which were still unorganized were included with Lycoming County.

sub_unit.name: Northampton
sub_unit.note: The official returns for Northampton County were 1157 votes for the Andrew Jackson ticket, 29 votes for the William H. Crawford ticket and 35 votes for the Henry Clay ticket. These official returns did not include the returns for Mount Bethel.

The Pennsylvanian (Easton, PA) lists 44 votes for the John Quincy Adams ticket and 35 votes for the Henry Clay ticket but the township totals add up to 55 votes for the John Quincy Adams ticket and 24 votes for the Henry Clay ticket.

sub_unit.name: Easton
sub_unit.note: The Berks and Schuykill Journal of November 6, 1824 lists 30 votes for William Crawford's ticket in the "Easton District" of Northampton County even though the November 13 edition lists only 29 votes for Crawford's ticket in the whole county. This is due to the disqualification of the votes from Mount Bethel.

The Berks and Schuykill Journal of November 6, 1824 lists 520 votes for the Andrew Jackson ticket, no votes for the John Quincy Adams ticket, 30 votes for the William H. Crawford ticket and 7 votes for the Henry Clay ticket.

sub_unit.name: Mount Bethel
sub_unit.note: "The votes of this district were not received in consequence of some alleged mismanagement in conducting their election." Pennsylvanian (Easton, PA). November 5, 1824.

sub_unit.name: Perry
sub_unit.note: The Reporter, which lists the township totals, lists the same county total of 24 votes for the John Quincy Adams ticket that other sources do, but the township totals only add up to 17 votes.

The Reporter lists individual township totals for the tickets, but not for the individual electors. It does list county totals for the individual electors. Therefore, it is unknown which township failed to give 1 vote each to Daniel Sheffer and John Pugh on the Andrew Jackson ticket and which township totals gave which votes to those individuals on the John Quincy Adams ticket, especially as the township totals do not add up for the Adams ticket.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: The Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA), Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) and The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA), which list the township totals list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 2266 votes and the John Quincy Adams ticket with 1496 votes.

The Berks and Schuylkill Journal (Reading, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 2264 votes, the John Quincy Adams ticket with 1500 votes, the William H. Crawford ticket with 580 votes and the Henry Clay ticket with 107 votes.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: The Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA), which lists the township totals lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 3494 votes, the John Quincy Adams ticket with 531 votes, the William H. Crawford ticket with 534 votes and the Henry Clay ticket with 88 votes.

The Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), which lists the township totals lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 3480 votes, the John Quincy Adams ticket with 531 votes, the William H. Crawford ticket with 542 votes and the Henry Clay ticket with 91 votes.

sub_unit.name: Blockley and Kingsessing
sub_unit.note: The Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 110 votes.

sub_unit.name: Germantown
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) lists the Henry Clay ticket with 5 votes.
The Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists the William H. Crawford ticket with 13 votes.

sub_unit.name: Moyamensing
sub_unit.note: Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 180 votes.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) and Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 180 votes, the John Quincy Adams ticket with 2 votes and the Henry Clay ticket with 5 votes.

sub_unit.name: Northern Liberties
sub_unit.note: Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 1203 votes.
The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) and Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 1203 votes and the John Quincy Adams ticket with 285 votes.

sub_unit.name: Oxford
sub_unit.note: Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists the Andrew Jackson ticket with 80 votes and the William H. Crawford ticket with 40 votes.
The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) and Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) list the Andrew Jackson ticket with 80 votes and the William H. Crawford ticket with 40 votes.

sub_unit.name: Penn
sub_unit.note: Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) and The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) list the John Quincy Adams ticket with 41 votes and the William H. Crawford ticket with 82 votes.

sub_unit.name: Westmoreland
sub_unit.note: "The apathy evinced in this election on Friday last, was striking, an may be known by the fact that in one of the townships of this district, but 10 votes were given in. The whole number of votes given in the county is 1006." The Greensburgh Gazette (Greensburg, PA). November 5, 1824.
The Westmoreland Republican, which lists the township totals, lists the John Quincy Adams ticket with 23 votes.
